newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanese pound loses ground against dollar.
newsitem.headline: Lebanese pound loses ground against dollar.

text.p: The Lebanese pound fell against the dollar in interbank trade on Thursday amid strong demand for the U.S. currency by a local bank, dealers said.

"One bank demanded a big amount of dollars in the last three days and that created some pressure on the market. This slowed interbank trade after the pound fell back to 1,546 per dollar," Talal Abou Zaki, Forex Manager for Bank Beirut and the Arab Countries told Reuters.
This was 4.5 pounds more than last week's closing interbank rate of 1,541.5, but within the central bank's bid-offer trading band which stood at 1,540-1,549.5 pounds per dollar.
Abou Zaki said banks traded the dollar on Thursday at between 1,544 and 1,546 pounds.
"If demand for dollars continues tomorrow like this the interbank rate could exceed 1,549.5 pound per dollar," Abou Zaki said.
This could bring central bank intervention to keep the pound within its trading band.

However, Abou Zaki said there was no reason to believe the situation was caused by concern about the pound on the market. "I believe the demand for dollars is just caused by the issue of a big deal by this one bank," he said.
